*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody or parenting arrangement may be modified upon a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the child.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the standard for making an initial custody determination—stating that the touchstone is the best interests of the child and listing factors to be weighed—but it does not address the legal standard for *modifying* an existing custody or parenting arrangement. There is no language in this decision about a requirement of a "material and substantial change in circumstances" as a predicate to modification, so it does not provide authority for that specific proposition of Massachusetts law.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … The best interests of the child standard is applied in the context of the particular needs and circumstances of the child in question.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Courts have consistently held that the best interests of the child must guide modifications of custody orders.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that removal decisions under the custody statute turn on whether the move is in the "best interests of the child" and that this standard is paramount. In discussing both the custody award and the removal issue, the court repeatedly frames the inquiry around the children’s best interests, confirming that such interests guide modifications affecting custody and residence. Although it is about initial and removal decisions rather than post-judgment modification motions generically, it clearly affirms the best-interests standard as controlling.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that "[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders." The words "upon cause shown" mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these "best interests" are to be determined.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.proposition: A child’s academic success and consistent education have long been recognized as central to the best interests of the child.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general ‘best interests of the child’ standard and factors like primary caretaker, parental conflict, and ability to cooperate, but it does not specifically identify academic success or consistent education as central or long‑recognized components of the best‑interests analysis. Education is mentioned only in passing as one of several areas of parental disagreement, not as a doctrinal focal point. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about academic success and consistent education being central to the best interests of the child.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398,.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children. … [T]he parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education…”

*Hoard v. Hoard*, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 710,.proposition: Where cooperation breaks down in ways that adversely affect the child, modification is appropriate.
*Hoard v. Hoard*, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 710,.case_name: P.J. Spillane Co. v. City of New Bedford
*Hoard v. Hoard*, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 710,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns bid deposits and the interpretation of “unforeseen circumstances” under a Massachusetts public bidding statute, not child custody, parental cooperation, or any issue involving a child’s welfare. It contains no discussion of breakdowns in cooperation or standards for modification of custody or parenting orders. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition that when cooperation breaks down in ways that adversely affect a child, modification is appropriate.
*Hoard v. Hoard*, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 710,.relevant_excerpt: "We think that ruling overlooked the only relevant case on the proper interpretation of the words ‘unforeseen circumstances’ as used in G. L. c. 149, § 44B. ... It follows that there is no occasion to inquire whether a ‘circumstance’ is ‘unforeseen’ unless the circumstance is one which arises after a bid has been submitted."

*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619, 624.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that regular school attendance is a fundamental obligation of parents and material to a child’s well-being.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619, 624.support_reasoning: The opinion is a divorce and custody case focused on property division, alimony, child support, and a technical issue about the proper procedural vehicle for modifying custody. While it discusses the children’s special emotional and educational needs and the parents’ roles in obtaining services and dealing with school personnel, it does not state or analyze any legal principle about regular school attendance being a fundamental parental obligation. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for that specific proposition.
*Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619, 624.relevant_excerpt: "The husband was essential in obtaining appropriate services for both children’s special needs. While the wife did more routine car transportation, the husband was equally involved in scheduling and attending meetings with treating professionals around the children’s unique issues and working with school personnel."

*Kendall v. Kendall*, 426 Mass. 238, 243.proposition: Defendant’s failure to prioritize Emily’s educational needs violates basic principles of shared legal custody and materially affects her best interests.
*Kendall v. Kendall*, 426 Mass. 238, 243.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss the defendant’s treatment of Emily, her educational needs, or how a parent’s failure to prioritize a child’s education violates principles of shared legal custody. Instead, Kendall v. Kendall addresses restrictions on a parent’s religious expression to avoid substantial emotional harm to the children and briefly upholds joint legal custody despite religious conflict. It therefore cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about Emily’s educational needs and shared legal custody.
*Kendall v. Kendall*, 426 Mass. 238, 243.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff argues on cross appeal that it was an abuse of discretion to award joint legal custody to the parties… The plaintiff argues that joint legal custody is inappropriate because she and the defendant are unable to agree on ‘major decisions regarding the [children’s]… moral and religious development.’… Because the plaintiff points to no conflict other than the parties’ inability to reconcile their views as to the children’s religious upbringing, we conclude that she has not established that the judge abused her discretion in granting joint custody.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 185 (.proposition: This Court has wide discretion to restructure parenting time in cases where one parent’s actions negatively impact the child’s education.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 185 (.support_reasoning: The case is a relocation/removal decision focused on whether moving the children out of Massachusetts is in their best interests, especially given one child’s special educational needs. While the opinion notes the child’s educational progress and the relative quality of school districts as factors in the best‑interests analysis, it does not discuss or endorse any general ‘wide discretion to restructure parenting time’ in response to a parent’s actions negatively affecting education. The trial judge continued shared custody and denied removal; the Supreme Judicial Court affirmed under an abuse‑of‑discretion standard, but did not articulate the proposition claimed.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 185 (.relevant_excerpt: “We turn to the propriety of the judge’s order denying permission for the mother to remove the children. The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests… From this the judge determined that it was not in the children’s best interests to be removed to Bristol.”

*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 18.proposition: This Court has wide discretion to restructure parenting time in cases where one parent’s actions negatively impact the child’s education.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 18.support_reasoning: The case does not deal with restructuring parenting time or visitation based on a parent’s negative impact on a child’s education. The only custody-related issue is a change from shared to sole legal custody, and the court actually vacates that change for lack of adequate findings; there is no discussion of parenting time or educational detriment as a basis for modifying it. The quoted language about the court’s “broad discretion” concerns financial security (attachment of assets) for support and college expenses, not restructuring parenting schedules.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 18.relevant_excerpt: “A Probate and Family Court judge has ‘broad discretion to fashion judgments in divorce proceedings that will best protect the interests and welfare of the parties’ minor children.’ Pare v. Pare, 409 Mass. 292, 298-299 (1991). The exact form of the order (or the decision to enter an order at all) is also within the judge’s broad discretion. Id. at 300.”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: A pattern of unilateral decision-making that harms the child’s welfare constitutes grounds for modifying an existing custody order.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion certainly affirms that abusive conduct by a parent that harms a child’s welfare can justify changing custody and even suspending visitation. However, the basis here is a statutory presumption arising from domestic abuse (G.L. c. 208, § 31A and c. 209A) and extensive findings of abuse, alienation, and lack of insight—not a general pattern of unilateral decision-making about the child. The court does not frame its custody modification authority in terms of unilateral decision-making as such, so the proposition is more specific than what this case actually decides.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: The judge’s decision to suspend visitation for one year is also supported by his extensive findings that over the course of their relationship, the father had engaged in physical, emotional, and financial abuse of the mother, and, in his interactions with the child, had damaged the mother’s relationship with the child. See G. L. c. 208, § 31A. Children who experience domestic violence, whether as direct witnesses or indirectly as members of the household in which violence occurs, “suffer deep and profound harms,” ... [T]he decision to suspend the father’s visitation rights with the child was based on the exercise of a sound discretion.

*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 656 (20.proposition: Safety, stability, and educational consistency constitute compelling reasons for revisiting and amending custody arrangements as per the best interests of the child.
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 656 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion is about the constitutionality and construction of a grandparent visitation statute, not about revisiting or amending custody arrangements. While it discusses the State’s compelling interest in protecting children from harm and mentions health, safety, and welfare in the context of best interests, it does not frame “safety, stability, and educational consistency” as compelling reasons to reopen or modify custody orders. The case therefore does not support the specific proposition claimed about grounds for revisiting custody arrangements.
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649, 656 (20.relevant_excerpt: “It cannot be disputed that the State has a compelling interest to protect children from actual or potential harm. … As we shall explain more fully below, the statute can be interpreted to require a showing of harm to the child if visitation is not allowed. So interpreted, the statute furthers a compelling and legitimate State interest in mitigating potential harm to children in nonintact families, an area in which the State has been traditionally and actively involved.”

*Furtado v. Furtado*, 380 Mass. 137 (198.proposition: Safety, stability, and educational consistency constitute compelling reasons for revisiting and amending custody arrangements as per the best interests of the child.
*Furtado v. Furtado*, 380 Mass. 137 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns criminal contempt for nonpayment of child support and procedural safeguards in contempt proceedings, not modification of custody orders. It does not discuss standards for revisiting or amending custody based on safety, stability, or educational consistency, nor does it frame such factors as compelling reasons under a best-interests analysis. Accordingly, the case does not provide authority for the proposition stated.
*Furtado v. Furtado*, 380 Mass. 137 (198.relevant_excerpt: A contempt proceeding for failure to comply with a support order may be brought as a civil contempt proceeding, as a criminal contempt proceeding, or as both a criminal and a civil contempt proceeding... Civil contempt proceedings are “remedial and coercive,” intended to achieve compliance with the court’s orders for the benefit of the complainant... On the other hand, a criminal contempt proceeding is “exclusively punitive. It is designed wholly to punish an attempt to prevent the course of justice.”
